member.name: T:CommandLine.OptParse.OptDefAttribute
member.summary: Define that a property or field can be given as an option
member.remarks:
For the property or field must have be type of bool
For the property or field must be a integer
For or the property or field must be the type of the property.
For the property or field must be an of values of the type defined by the property (IList cannot be null).

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.OptDefAttribute.#ctor(CommandLine.OptParse.OptValType)
member.summary: Constructor
member.param: The type of value the option takes or null to use the type of the property/field

member.name: P:CommandLine.OptParse.OptDefAttribute.ValueType
member.summary: Get or set the type of value to support
member.remarks: For most properties and fields, this is optional (can be left null), but for IList types of properties that take multiple values, this property needs to be set to know how to convert the command-line values to the type the list expects

member.remarks: By default, the name of a property or field is used as a option name when defined as an option (see ). This attribute allows only names to be given using and attributes. If this attribute value is false, one of the above attributes must be given for the property

member.name: T:CommandLine.OptParse.DefaultUsageInfo
member.summary: A simple, default implementation of that is fairly easy to use

member.name: T:CommandLine.OptParse.IProgUsageInfo
member.summary: Interface for the parser to use to be able to print usage information for the given program.
member.remarks: The usage structure is similar to the Perl POD structure, of headers with description blocks. The implementation however is not as robust.

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.IProgUsageInfo.IsOptionHeader(System.String)
member.summary: Check if a given header should contain the usage of the options
member.param: The header to check
member.returns: True if the contents of this header is the options description

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.IProgUsageInfo.GetContents(System.String)
member.summary: Get the contents of a non-option header
member.param: The header to get the contents for

member.name: P:CommandLine.OptParse.IProgUsageInfo.Headers
member.summary: Get a list of all the "topic" headers for the usage
member.remarks: Each header is similar to a header in a Unix man page. The header is a title block for the contents to follow. The usage information is broken up into sections, each started with a header. Typical headers are "Description", "Synopsis", "Options", "Arguments"

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.DefaultUsageInfo.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.String[])
member.summary: Constructor to make argument description construction easier
member.param: The name of the program (something.exe)
Description of the program
True to use all-upper case headers, or false for title cased headers
list of descriptions in the format of { "Argument", "Description" [, "Argument", "Description"] ...}

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.DefaultUsageInfo.#ctor(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Collections.Specialized.NameValueCollection)
member.summary: Constructor
member.param: The name of the program (something.exe)
Description of the program
True to use all-upper case headers, or false for title cased headers
Argument name, argument description pairs to describe the arguments the program takes or null if none

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.DefaultUsageInfo.IsOptionHeader(System.String)
member.summary: Get if the given header should hold the option description
member.param: The header

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.DefaultUsageInfo.GetContents(System.String)
member.summary: Get the contents of the given header

member.name: P:CommandLine.OptParse.DefaultUsageInfo.Headers
member.summary: Get the headers for the usage

member.summary: Define the behavior of the parser if an option is given that is not reconginzed

member.summary: Do not do anything, the option will be considered an argument

member.summary: A warning will be sent back to the caller of the parser (see the event)

member.summary: Stop parsing, throwing a

member.name: T:CommandLine.OptParse.DupOptHandleType
member.summary: Define the behavior of the parser if an option is duplicated
member.remarks: If the option is not defined as a option that allows multiple values, then this enumeration specifies the action to take when a duplicate option is given at the command-line.

member.name: F:CommandLine.OptParse.DupOptHandleType.Allow
member.summary: Allow the duplicate declaration, using the last declaration to specify the value

member.name: F:CommandLine.OptParse.DupOptHandleType.Warning
member.summary: Allow the duplicate declaration, using the last declaration to specify the value, but send a warning back to the caller of the parser (see the event)

member.name: F:CommandLine.OptParse.DupOptHandleType.Error
member.summary: Deny the duplicate declaration, throwing a

member.name: T:CommandLine.OptParse.OptStyle
member.summary: The platform style of option

member.name: F:CommandLine.OptParse.OptStyle.Windows
member.summary: Windows style of options (/opt)
member.remarks:
Use options in the standard Windows format. Example:
program.exe /opt1:"Option 1 Value" /opt2:Opt2Value /opt3
Windows arguments do not differentiate between short an long formats like Unix arguments.

member.name: F:CommandLine.OptParse.OptStyle.Unix
member.summary: Unix style of options (--opt, -o)
member.remarks:
Use options in the standard Unix format. Example:
program --opt1="Option 1 Value" --opt2 Opt2Value -o
Long argument values may be separated from the option by a space or by an equal sign. Short option values are separated from the option by a space

member.name: T:CommandLine.OptParse.UnixShortOption
member.summary: Specify how short options may be given for Unix-style arguments

member.name: F:CommandLine.OptParse.UnixShortOption.CollapseShort
member.summary: Allow short arguments to be collapsed.
member.remarks:
Example:
Program -abcd 0 "This is d's value"
If the options require a value (See enum), then the the values after the arguments will be applied in order. Optional arguments that precede required arguments become required, meaning that if 3 values are given for 4 values (i.e. program -abcd val1 val2 val3), and the first two arguments have optional values, and the 3rd is required, and the fourth takes an optional value, then per the example, the value of 'val1' will be assigned to 'a', 'val2' to 'b', and 'val3' to 'c' with 'd' not having a value.

member.name: F:CommandLine.OptParse.UnixShortOption.ShortSeparated
member.summary: Short options must be separated, and values do not need a space after the name
member.remarks: Example: program -a -b -c0 -d"This is d's value"

member.name: T:CommandLine.OptParse.OptValType
member.summary: Type of value that the option permits

member.name: F:CommandLine.OptParse.OptValType.Flag
member.summary: The option does not accept a value

member.name: F:CommandLine.OptParse.OptValType.IncrementalFlag
member.summary: The option does not accept a value, but may be declared multiple times
member.remarks: This type of argument supports multiple declaration. For example, --verbose --verbose --verbose, could be used to allow a 3rd level of verbose information to be printed by a program.

member.name: F:CommandLine.OptParse.OptValType.ValueReq
member.summary: The option requires a value. If a value is not supplied, an error will be thrown

member.name: F:CommandLine.OptParse.OptValType.ValueOpt
member.summary: The option optional takes a value

member.name: F:CommandLine.OptParse.OptValType.MultValue
member.summary: The option allows 0 to many values

member.name: T:CommandLine.OptParse.IOptionResults
member.summary: Interface for interacting with the results of parsing the options
member.remarks:
This interface allows for storing option results in different formats. The class uses this interface.
The implementation of this interface should be able to index the option definitions in both a case sensitive and case insensitive format. The parser's settings will determine the case sesitivity that will be used.

member.returns: The definition of the option or null if there is no option defined for the given name

member.name: T:CommandLine.OptParse.OptionDefinition
member.summary: Definition of an option
member.remarks: Use this class to define possible options for a command-line. This is an alternative to using a class with fields and properties defined as options.

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.OptionDefinition.CreateDefinitions(System.String[])
member.summary: Helper method to create OptionDefinition instances for each string in definitions
member.param: Definitions (See )

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.OptionDefinition.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Build an option from a Perl-like string syntax
member.remarks:
The definition must match the following regular expression syntax: ^[\w|]+([:=+][sifd]?)?$.
Explanation:
Part Description
[\w|]+ A series of one or more word or character names separated by pipe ('|') characters. Example: help|h|?. In this example, for Unix-style options, the valid option variations would be: --help, -h or -?
[:=+] A character to define the type of value expected. This is optional, and if not given, the option will be considered a flag. So a definition of help can be given at the command-line like: Program --help. The ':' and '=' requires the type of value (see below). The '+' can be used in two ways. First, it can mean that a flag can be given multiple times (to be counted for example). This usage: verbose+ can be given like: Program --verbose --verbose --verbose to result in a verbosity of 3. With a type of value (see below), it means that the option can have many values. A value of ':' means the option may take a value, and '=' means that a value is required for this option.
[sifd]? A character to define the type of data to accept. This is optional if the preceding character is '+' (see above). If given, the values map to the following .NET types: s - String, i - Int32, d - Double and f - Float
Examples:
Flag: Example show help: help|h|? Flag that gets counted: Example to set level of verbosity: verbose|v+ Option with a required string value (Example: set an output directory): Example to set an output directory: directory|dir|d=s Option with an optional integer value: Example to count value that defaults to 0: count|c:i Option that accepts multiple string values: Example to specify include patters: include|i+s
member.param: The option definition

member.summary: Constructor
member.param: ID of the option

the type of value that the option supports (if values are supported, ignored otherwise)

member.name: T:CommandLine.OptParse.Parser
member.summary: Class that parses the command line options. Use the to construct an instance of a parser
member.remarks: Class that

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.Parser.#ctor(CommandLine.OptParse.IOptionResults)
member.summary: Constructor

remarks.para: The object is resposible for maintaining the option definitions and stores the results of parsing.
The class can assist with constructing instances of the parser (handles object creating). If the factory is not used, the and classes can be used.

member.param: The interface containing the option definitions and handles the results of parsing.

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.Parser.GetOptionDefinitions
member.summary: Get all of the option definitions that have been declared

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.Parser.GetOptionDescriptions(CommandLine.OptParse.OptStyle)
member.summary: Get a collection of option value, option description pairs
member.remarks:
Used to help print the usage of the application. This function concatinates the options together into one string that is used as the key of the collection, and then sets the value as the description of the option.
Example result:
Key : -h, --help Value: Print the usage of this application
Here, the key is a comma concatination of the options and the value is the description of that option.
Short names will precede the long options in the key.
member.param: The style of options. During concatination, the appropriate prefix ('/', '-' or '--') will be added to each option name
member.returns: Collection of the options and their descriptions

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.Parser.PrintUsage(CommandLine.OptParse.OptStyle,CommandLine.OptParse.IProgUsageInfo,System.Int32)
member.summary: Prints out the usage of this program to the given text writer
member.remarks:
Prints the usage to the standard output. See and for more information on how the usage is printed.
At this time, wrapping is not done at word boundries
member.param: The style of the options to have printed in the usage
The number of columns to print before wrapping the text. Used to correctly format the indenting

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.Parser.PrintUsage(CommandLine.OptParse.OptStyle,CommandLine.OptParse.IProgUsageInfo,System.IO.TextWriter,System.Int32)

member.param: The style of the options to have printed in the usage

The number of columns to print before wrapping the text. Used to correctly format the indenting

member.summary: Parse the arguments for options using the given settings

How to parse unix short options (ignored if not unix style parsing)
How to handle un-expected duplicate option definitions

member.remarks: At this time wrapping is not done at a word boundry

The writer to print to

member.name: P:CommandLine.OptParse.Parser.SearchEnvironment
member.summary: Get or set to search the environment names for values to the options
member.remarks: If set to true, environment variable values will be used if found and the options are not given on the command line. The prefixes (--, -, or /) are not used, only the names of the options when searching the environment.

member.name: T:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder
member.summary: Class to assist the building of program usage information
member.remarks: The API of this class is similar to that of an . The output of the usage is an . The using the , and methods the XML can be transformed into the desired output format for the usage.

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.#ctor
member.summary: Default constructor

member.summary: Convenience method for transforming the XML using a custom XSLT
member.param: TextWriter to write the output to
Xslt content to use to transform with
Xslt arguments to pass to the

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.ToHtml(System.IO.TextWriter,CommandLine.OptParse.OptStyle,System.Uri,System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Convert the usage to HTML
member.param: TextWriter to write the output to
The style to use when printing possible option names
Stylesheet URI to apply to the HTML content
True to include the default option values in the output
Title to use for the HTML page

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.ToText(System.IO.TextWriter,CommandLine.OptParse.OptStyle,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Convert the usage to Text
member.param: TextWriter to write the output to
The style to use when printing possible option names
True to include the default option values in the output

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.ToText(System.IO.TextWriter,CommandLine.OptParse.OptStyle,System.Boolean,System.Int32)
member.summary: Convert the usage to Text
member.remarks: if is -1, the width of the console will be used on windows machines, and the text will not be wrapped on non-windows machines
member.param: TextWriter to write the output to
The style to use when printing possible option names
True to include the default option values in the output
Wrap text at the given column (attempts to wrap at '-' or ' ')

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.BeginSection(System.String)
member.summary: Begin a new section tag
member.remarks: May only be under a "usage" or "section" tag. must be called to close this tag
member.param: Name of the section

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.EndSection
member.summary: Close the section
member.remarks: Section tag must be active

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.AddParagraph(System.String)
member.summary: Add a paragraph to the usage
member.remarks: May only be inside of "section" or "description" tags
member.param: The body of the paragraph

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.BeginParagraph
member.summary: Add a paragraph to the usage
member.remarks: May only be inside of "section" or "description" tags. must be called to close this tag. Use to add text to the paragraph body.

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.AddParagraphContent(System.String)
member.summary: Add content to the current paragraph node
member.remarks: May only be called when a "para" tag is active.
member.param: Text to add

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.EndParagraph
member.summary: Close the active "para" tag
member.remarks: May only be called when a "para" tag is active.

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.BeginList(CommandLine.OptParse.ListType)
member.summary: Open a list tag
member.remarks: Sets the active tag to a new "list" tag. May only be called when one of the following tags are active: "section", "paragraph", "list", "description". must be called to close this tag
member.param: The type of list

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.AddListItem(System.String)
member.summary: Add a list item tag to the current list
member.remarks: May only be called when a "list" tag is active.
member.param: Body of the list item to add

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.EndList
member.summary: Close the active "list" tag
member.remarks: May only be called when a "list" tag is active.

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.BeginOptions
member.summary: Begin an active "options" tag
member.remarks: May only be called when a "header" tag is active.

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.EndOptions
member.summary: Close the active "options" tag
member.remarks: May only be called when a "options" tag is active.

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.BeginOption(CommandLine.OptParse.OptionDefinition)
member.summary: Method to start adding an option to the usage.
member.remarks: Leaves the "description" tag as the active tag. Allows paragraph and list content to be added to the description of an option beyond the normal description. Does not include the description body from the (must be added manually). Call to close this tag.
member.param: Option to start

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.EndOption
member.summary: Close the active "description" tag and "option" tags
member.remarks: May only be called when a "description" tag is active below an "option" tag.

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.AddOptions(CommandLine.OptParse.IOptionContainer)
member.summary: Add multiple options to the output
member.remarks: Can only be called if the active tag is "section"
member.param: Container with all the options for the program to document

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.AddOptions(CommandLine.OptParse.OptionDefinition[])
member.summary: Add multiple options to the output
member.remarks: Can only be called if the active tag is "section"
member.param: All the options for the program

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.AddOption(CommandLine.OptParse.OptionDefinition)
member.summary: Adds an option to the output
member.remarks: Like , but uses the desription from the option as the body of the "description" tag. Does not open a new active tag
member.param: Option to add

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.BeginArguments
member.summary: Begin an active "arguments" tag
member.remarks: May only be called when a "header" tag is active.

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.EndArguments
member.summary: Close the active "arguments" tag
member.remarks: May only be called when an "arguments" tag is active.

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.AddArgument(System.String,System.String,System.Type,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Add an argument overview to the usage
member.remarks: Can only be called when a "section" tag is active. Does not leave a new active tag open.
member.param: Short name description of the argument
Description of the argument
Supported data type for the argument (typeof(string) is usually the best choice).
True if the argument should be marked as optional

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.BeginArgument(System.String,System.Type,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Add an argument overview to the usage
member.remarks: Can only be called when an "arguments" tag is active. Leaves the "description" tag active under the "argument" tag.
member.param: Short name description of the argument
Supported data type for the argument (typeof(string) is usually the best choice).
True if the argument should be marked as optional

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.EndArgument
member.summary: Close the active "description" tag and "argument" tags
member.remarks: May only be called when a "description" tag is active below an "argument" tag.

member.name: P:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.Usage
member.summary: Get the containing the usage content

member.name: P:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.DefaultOptionCategory
member.summary: Get or set the category to use for options when an option is missing a category
member.remarks: Cannot be set to null or an empty string, if so, the default value will be used

member.name: P:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.GroupOptionsByCategory
member.summary: Get or set to group options by their categories

member.summary: Class to help with Text transformation

member.summary: Constructor
member.param: Column to wrap at

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.TextTransformHelper.CreateSpaces(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create a string of spaces
member.param: Length of the string to create

member.name: M:CommandLine.OptParse.UsageBuilder.TextTransformHelper.FormatText(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Formats text, adding indent and wrapping lines

Indent to add to each line
Additional indent to add to lines after the first
